articles.headline: You’re Buying a Home. Have You Considered Climate Change?
articles.snippet: It’s a smart idea to consider the long-term implications of owning a home in damage-prone areas.
articles.abstract: It’s a smart idea to consider the long-term implications of owning a home in damage-prone areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: So you want to buy a home in a global warming zone.

articles.headline: Trump Treasury May Mean Independence for Fannie and Freddie
articles.snippet: By suggesting that the companies would be freed from government control, Steven Mnuchin backed an approach that would benefit small lenders and borrowers.
articles.abstract: By suggesting that the companies would be freed from government control, Steven Mnuchin backed an approach that would benefit small lenders and borrowers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steven Mnuchin, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s nominee to run the Treasury Department, electrified Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac shareholders on Wednesday when he signaled that the mortgage finance giants would finally be allowed to get out from under Washington’s thumb.

articles.headline: Trump’s Tough Trade Talk Could Damage American Factories
articles.snippet: If President-elect Donald J. Trump imposes steep tariffs on Chinese goods, he could harm the people he aims to help — American factory workers.
articles.abstract: If President-elect Donald J. Trump imposes steep tariffs on Chinese goods, he could harm the people he aims to help — American factory workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLLAND, Mich. — While much of the American political class has been consumed with recriminations over the wrenching loss of manufacturing jobs, Chuck Reid has been quietly adding them.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman, Neil Gough, Sui-Lee Wee and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Ads Show Up on Breitbart and Brands Blame Technology
articles.snippet: How does a progressive company find itself pitched on a hard-right website? A third-party ad network is using consumer data and targeting technology.
articles.abstract: How does a progressive company find itself pitched on a hard-right website? A third-party ad network is using consumer data and targeting technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Vanguard Group does its best to stay away from politics when advertising, going so far as to have a policy against marketing on overtly partisan websites. So it was a surprise to Vanguard, an investment management company, when it found its ads on Breitbart News, the hard-right site that has become closely tied to President-elect Donald J. Trump.

articles.headline: Trump Speaks With Taiwan’s Leader, an Affront to China
articles.snippet: The president-elect spoke by phone with the president of Taiwan in the first such contact since the United States severed diplomatic relations with the island.
articles.abstract: The president-elect spoke by phone with the president of Taiwan in the first such contact since the United States severed diplomatic relations with the island.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump spoke by telephone with Taiwan’s president on Friday, a striking break with nearly four decades of diplomatic practice that could precipitate a major rift with China even before Mr. Trump takes office.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Obama Moves to Block Chinese Acquisition of a German Chip Maker
articles.snippet: The White House’s intervention could set the stage for President-elect Donald Trump to take a tougher stance on foreign deals.
articles.abstract: The White House’s intervention could set the stage for President-elect Donald Trump to take a tougher stance on foreign deals.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — President Obama on Friday moved to block a Chinese deal to buy a high-tech company on national security grounds, an unusual step that could set the stage for greater tensions between his successor, Donald J. Trump, and a Chinese government determined to bolster its technological capabilities.

articles.headline: Campus Press vs. Colleges: Kentucky Suit Highlights Free-Speech Fight
articles.snippet: The suit against a campus paper that reported a woman’s allegation against a professor pits students seeking information and administrators concerned about privacy.
articles.abstract: The suit against a campus paper that reported a woman’s allegation against a professor pits students seeking information and administrators concerned about privacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The confidential informant had an explosive tip for the University of Kentucky’s campus newspaper: An associate professor of entomology had been accused of groping students, and the college, after an investigation, had permitted him to leave quietly.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Plans Immediate Repeal of Health Law, Then a Delay
articles.snippet: Congressional Republicans plan to move quickly to repeal the Affordable Care Act, but they are also likely to delay the effective date.
articles.abstract: Congressional Republicans plan to move quickly to repeal the Affordable Care Act, but they are also likely to delay the effective date.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans in Congress plan to move almost immediately next month to repeal the Affordable Care Act, as President-elect Donald J. Trump promised. But they also are likely to delay the effective date so that they have several years to phase out President Obama’s signature achievement.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear, Jennifer Steinhauer and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: How Big Banks Are Putting Rain Forests in Peril
articles.snippet: Global lenders, sometimes flouting their own policies, have financed projects in Indonesia and elsewhere that destroy ecosystems and contribute to climate change.
articles.abstract: Global lenders, sometimes flouting their own policies, have financed projects in Indonesia and elsewhere that destroy ecosystems and contribute to climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: In early 2015, scientists monitoring satellite images at Global Forest Watch raised the alarm about the destruction of rain forests in Indonesia.

articles.headline: From Michael Lewis, a Portrait of the Men Who Shaped ‘Moneyball’
articles.snippet: The best-selling author studied the work of two psychologists and chronicled their unusual partnership of ideas in the book “The Undoing Project.”
articles.abstract: The best-selling author studied the work of two psychologists and chronicled their unusual partnership of ideas in the book “The Undoing Project.”
articles.lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, Michael Lewis was following a group of young baseball players through the minor leagues. He was working on a sequel to his 2003 best seller “Moneyball,” which chronicled how the Oakland A’s general manager Billy Beane revolutionized the sport by using statistics to evaluate players.

articles.headline: Standing Rock Pipeline Protesters, Ordered to Leave, Dig In
articles.snippet: “I ain’t going nowhere,” one man said as he and fellow protesters on the frozen prairie prepared for what they believe may be their last stand.
articles.abstract: “I ain’t going nowhere,” one man said as he and fellow protesters on the frozen prairie prepared for what they believe may be their last stand.
articles.lead_paragraph: CANNON BALL, N.D. — Lee Plenty Wolf knows the government wants him to clear out of the snowbound tepee where he stokes the fire, sings traditional Oglala songs and sleeps alongside a pair of women from France and California who came to protest an oil pipeline in the stinging cold. But he and thousands of other protesters are vowing to make what may be their last stand at Standing Rock.

articles.headline: Extremists Turn to a Leader to Protect Western Values: Vladimir Putin
articles.snippet: In retrospect, Donald J. Trump’s praise for Russia’s president seems to have been a shrewd dog whistle to a small but highly motivated part of the Trump base.
articles.abstract: In retrospect, Donald J. Trump’s praise for Russia’s president seems to have been a shrewd dog whistle to a small but highly motivated part of the Trump base.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the founder of the Traditionalist Worker Party, an American group that aims to preserve the privileged place of whiteness in Western civilization and fight “anti-Christian degeneracy,” Matthew Heimbach knows whom he envisions as the ideal ruler: the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer and Andrew Higgins

articles.headline: In Trump’s Security Pick, Michael Flynn, ‘Sharp Elbows’ and No Dissent
articles.snippet: Past colleagues paint a mixed picture of a man who will have nearly unfettered access to the Oval Office and help guide President Trump on world events.
articles.abstract: Past colleagues paint a mixed picture of a man who will have nearly unfettered access to the Oval Office and help guide President Trump on world events.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Days after Islamist militants stormed the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, in 2012, Lt. Gen. Michael T. Flynn reached a conclusion that stunned some of his subordinates at the Defense Intelligence Agency: Iran had a role in the attack, he told them.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg, Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Donald Trump Thrusts Taiwan Back on the Table, Rattling a Region
articles.snippet: A single protocol-shattering phone call with Taiwan’s president raises fears of igniting tensions in Asia and emboldening China.
articles.abstract: A single protocol-shattering phone call with Taiwan’s president raises fears of igniting tensions in Asia and emboldening China.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over the past two decades, Taiwan has slipped from its position atop the list of flash points in the complex relationship between the United States and China. In meetings between President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China, it has typically come up after half a dozen more pressing issues, like trade, cyberattacks and Beijing’s aggressive moves in the South China Sea.

articles.headline: Business Since Birth: Trump’s Children and the Tangle That Awaits
articles.snippet: The president-elect’s three eldest children have always interwoven family and business ties. Can their empire ever be separate from the White House?
articles.abstract: The president-elect’s three eldest children have always interwoven family and business ties. Can their empire ever be separate from the White House?
articles.lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump hosted a foreign leader for the first time as president-elect, the guest list included a curious entry: Mr. Trump’s daughter Ivanka, who looked on last month while he and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan chatted on a white couch high above Manhattan.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer, Rachel Abrams, Barry Meier and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Italy’s Premier, Matteo Renzi, Says He’ll Resign After Reform Is Rejected
articles.snippet: Voters defeated proposed changes to Italy’s Constitution, handing a win to anti-establishment forces on the Continent.
articles.abstract: Voters defeated proposed changes to Italy’s Constitution, handing a win to anti-establishment forces on the Continent.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Italy plunged into political and economic uncertainty early Monday as Prime Minister Matteo Renzi said he would resign after voters decisively rejected constitutional changes, a step certain to reverberate across a European Union already buffeted by anti-establishment anger.

articles.headline: Vowing to Squeeze Businesses, Trump Has Tactics Challenged
articles.snippet: Economists from both ends of the political spectrum say the president-elect’s approach of berating and rewarding companies may be good political theater but ultimately ineffective.
articles.abstract: Economists from both ends of the political spectrum say the president-elect’s approach of berating and rewarding companies may be good political theater but ultimately ineffective.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald Trump isn’t done taunting corporate America.

articles.headline: Death Toll in Oakland Warehouse Fire Rises to 36 as Search Continues
articles.snippet: Officials said that the search of the rubble of a makeshift nightclub in the building would take days, and that they expected the number of victims to rise.
articles.abstract: Officials said that the search of the rubble of a makeshift nightclub in the building would take days, and that they expected the number of victims to rise.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Carmen Brito was asleep on Friday night when she suddenly woke up gasping for breath. Outside her small studio, one floor down from where a raging concert was taking place, she saw her neighbor’s wall on fire.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller, Conor Dougherty and Julie Turkewitz

articles.headline: Silicon Valley’s Culture, Not Its Companies, Dominates in China
articles.snippet: China’s internet filters block many of Silicon Valley’s biggest companies but have done little to stanch a Chinese obsession with its culture.
articles.abstract: China’s internet filters block many of Silicon Valley’s biggest companies but have done little to stanch a Chinese obsession with its culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — The majesty of the Golden Gate, the windy chill of Alcatraz, the tourist hubbub of Pier 39 — Zhao Haoyu’s itinerary for San Francisco had it all.

articles.headline: Protesters Gain Victory in Fight Over Dakota Access Oil Pipeline
articles.snippet: The Army said it would look for other routes for the pipeline, a victory for the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe in a battle that has become a global flash point.
articles.abstract: The Army said it would look for other routes for the pipeline, a victory for the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe in a battle that has become a global flash point.
articles.lead_paragraph: CANNON BALL, N.D. — The Standing Rock Sioux Tribe won a major victory on Sunday in its battle to block an oil pipeline being built near its reservation when the Department of the Army announced that it would not allow the pipeline to be drilled under a dammed section of the Missouri River.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: Tomi Lahren: Young, Vocal and the Right’s Rising Media Star
articles.snippet: Ms. Lahren, who became a visible supporter of Donald J. Trump during the presidential campaign, has drawn the ire of critics who say her commentaries are often racist.
articles.abstract: Ms. Lahren, who became a visible supporter of Donald J. Trump during the presidential campaign, has drawn the ire of critics who say her commentaries are often racist.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I’m in the lion’s den, Trevor.”

articles.headline: A Warning for Americans From a Member of Pussy Riot
articles.snippet: Nadya Tolokonnikova, who was imprisoned for a 2012 performance, sees similarities between the situation in Russia and post-election America.
articles.abstract: Nadya Tolokonnikova, who was imprisoned for a 2012 performance, sees similarities between the situation in Russia and post-election America.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH — On Tuesday, Donald J. Trump wrote on Twitter that people who burn the flag should be punished with “perhaps loss of citizenship or year in jail!”

articles.headline: SoftBank’s Masayoshi Son Chases First Place With Tech Deals
articles.snippet: With two ambitious projects, Masayoshi Son, who created the parent company of Sprint, bets big on having a say in an increasingly mobile world.
articles.abstract: With two ambitious projects, Masayoshi Son, who created the parent company of Sprint, bets big on having a say in an increasingly mobile world.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Masayoshi Son is a Japanese billionaire who wants to control the way your car talks to street lamps.
